importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was published on October 21, 2025, marking the release of Cory Doctorow's new book titled 'Enshittification,' which presents a detailed theory about the degradation of internet platforms.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2023 to 2025 is significant because it is when the term 'enshittification' gained widespread use, including being named Word of the Year by the American Dialect Society and added to Merriam-Webster’s dictionary.

keyTakeAways: The term 'enshittification' describes the decline of internet platforms like Facebook, Google, Amazon, and Uber from being user-friendly and valuable in their early stages to becoming exploitative and degrading in later stages.

Enshittification occurs in three stages: Stage 1 (growth and user acquisition), Stage 2 (favoring business customers at user expense), and Stage 3 (profit maximization at the cost of users and merchants).

In Stage 3, platforms such as Facebook and Amazon are accused of charging excessive fees, manipulating algorithms, and promoting ads or boosted content over user preferences, leading to worse experiences for consumers and businesses.
Doctorow cites studies showing that Amazon’s search results often display higher-priced items higher up in results and that the best match can be as far as 17 places down, increasing consumer costs.

Amazon and Facebook have responded to Doctorow’s claims by stating that their platforms have improved over time and that his assertions about 'cloning' products or 'junk fees' are false or misleading.
The core explanation for enshittification lies in a lack of competition and weak consumer protection regulations, especially under the 'consumer welfare standard' in antitrust law.

Doctorow advocates for stronger antitrust enforcement, 'right-to-exit' regulations (e.g., allowing users to take their data or e-books with them), and improved interoperability between platforms to break down monopolistic barriers.

namedEntities.name: Cory Doctorow
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Author, internet activist, and journalist who coined the term 'enshittification' and wrote a new book on the topic.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Doctorow is central to the article as the originator of the concept and the primary analyst behind the theory of enshittification in internet platforms.

namedEntities.name: Enshittification
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A term coined by Cory Doctorow to describe the degradation of internet platforms, where user experience deteriorates due to profit-driven decisions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The core concept of the article — the decline of platforms like Facebook and Amazon — is framed entirely around the phenomenon of enshittification.

namedEntities.name: Facebook (Meta)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major social media platform that Doctorow critiques for shifting from user-focused to ad-driven, algorithmic content delivery.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Facebook is a primary example of enshittification, illustrating how platforms transition from user-friendly early stages to prioritizing ad revenue and data monetization.

namedEntities.name: Google
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major search and advertising platform, referenced in the article as one of the platforms undergoing enshittification.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Google is included in Doctorow’s list of platforms that have evolved from being helpful to prioritizing ad revenue and business customer profits at user expense.

namedEntities.name: Amazon
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An e-commerce giant accused by Doctorow of exploiting merchants through junk fees, algorithm manipulation, and poor search quality.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Amazon is a central case study in enshittification, particularly in Stage 3, where it is claimed to charge high fees and manipulate search results to benefit its own interests.

namedEntities.name: Uber
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A ride-sharing platform cited by Doctorow as part of the broader pattern of enshittification in internet services.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Uber is included in the list of platforms showing the devolution from user value to profit extraction, illustrating the pattern across industries.

namedEntities.name: American Dialect Society
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An organization that named 'enshittification' its Word of the Year in 2023.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The recognition of the term by the American Dialect Society underscores its cultural and linguistic significance in public discourse about internet platforms.

namedEntities.name: Merriam-Webster
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A dictionary publisher that added 'enshittification' to its dictionary despite the term containing a swear word.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Merriam-Webster’s inclusion of the term highlights its widespread acceptance and cultural penetration beyond niche internet circles.

namedEntities.name: Institute for Local Self-Reliance
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A non-profit research and advocacy group cited by Doctorow as a source of data on Amazon’s fees.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This organization provided the study that supports Doctorow’s claim that Amazon takes 45–51 cents per dollar in fees from merchants.

namedEntities.name: Planet Money
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A NPR podcast that features the article and discusses antitrust and internet regulation.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Planet Money serves as a medium that amplifies the discussion around enshittification and antitrust policy, linking it to broader public policy debates.

namedEntities.name: Right-to-exit
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A proposed policy allowing users to take their data or content (e.g. e-books) with them when leaving a platform.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This policy is proposed by Doctorow as a mechanism to incentivize better user treatment and reduce platform power.

namedEntities.name: Interoperability
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A technical concept allowing different products or services to work together, such as different apps or devices communicating.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Doctorow argues that lack of interoperability is a tool used by companies to maintain monopolies, and recommends regulation to enforce it.

namedEntities.name: Consumer Welfare Standard
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An antitrust legal doctrine that judges monopolistic behavior based on consumer price increases rather than broader harm.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Doctorow argues that this standard undermines effective regulation of tech monopolies and must be reformed to address enshittification.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Cory Doctorow, a prominent internet activist and journalist, introduces his new book titled 'Enshittification' to describe how major internet platforms such as Facebook, Google, Amazon, and Uber have degraded from user-focused, early-stage services into exploitative, profit-driven systems. He outlines a three-stage process: Stage 1, where platforms grow rapidly and offer attractive, user-friendly experiences; Stage 2, where they prioritize business customers by manipulating feeds and offering subsidies; and Stage 3, where they aggressively extract profit through inflated fees, algorithmic manipulation, and poor search results, ultimately harming both users and merchants. Doctorow attributes this decline to a lack of competition and insufficient regulation, especially under the consumer welfare standard. He proposes policy solutions such as 'right-to-exit' regulations and improved interoperability to restore user trust and platform integrity. While Amazon and Facebook deny the claims, Doctorow supports them with data from studies and advocacy organizations, and the article frames enshittification as a critical issue for internet sustainability and democratic access to digital services.
title: A theory why the internet is going down the toilet
